abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews some 1999 French bordeaux wines; map (M)

block.p: Man proposes and Mother Nature disposes, so buying wine, in bottles or futures, is always a gamble. But the globalization of up-to-date vineyard and cellar techniques, with Bordeaux on the cutting edge, has so reduced risk that longstanding skepticism about the guidepost value of vintage charts has ratched up even higher.

Although Bordeaux 99's are generally iffy, if not downright poor, many savory wines can be found, as in all troubled vintages everywhere. Good values have been spawned by a combination of the vintage's low reputation, producers' reduced prices and the dollar's strength against the franc.

Zachys, 16 East Parkway in Scarsdale, is advertising an attractive range of '99 Bordeaux reds as futures for $240 a case ($20 a bottle) and under (and over), all based on staffers' tastings of barrel samples in the region. You pay now and take delivery in 2002 (remember, potential income sacrificed from alternate investments adds, in effect, to the price).
The following '99 reds, all in standard-size bottles and listed by appellations, chateaus and Zachys's case prices, merit attention:
Margaux: Cantenac Brown ($239), d'Issan ($229), du Tertre ($225), Giscours ($239), Siran ($199).
St.-Julien: Branaire ($225), Gloria ($219), Les Fiefs de Lagrange (the second wine of Lagrange, $155, a good buy).
St.-Estephe: Lafon-Rochet ($239), Les Ormes de Pez ($205), Meyney ($199).
Graves: Carbonnieux ($219), Haut-Bergey ($175), La Louviere ($210), Malartic-Lagraviere ($239), Olivier ($199, a good buy).
Pomerol: De Sales ($195), Mazeyres ($195), Petit Eglise ($205).
